author: vdanche
body:
.NET 7 preview7 installed on locale OS(e.g DE)

Repro:
Step1:Install wasm-tools

dotnet workload install wasm-tools --skip-manifest-update

            Step3: New blazorWasm 

                            dotnet new blazorwasm 
Step2: dotnet publish with AOT enable
Adding “true” to csproj file to use AOT compilation, like this

`<PropertyGroup> <TargetFramework>net7.0</TargetFramework> <RunAOTCompilation>true</RunAOTCompilation></PropertyGroup>`

Check if strings are localized well.
Expected Result:
Strings are localized well

Actual Result:
Step1:
Some strings are not localized well during installing workload

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65637796/178241075-3ab0c6c4-e793-4a44-83e5-da863def6c11.png)


Step2;
Some strings are not localized well during publishing
E.g(DE)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65637796/178239630-b20ab068-c283-44f2-8e3d-0cc04da36bc0.png)

nodes.author: marcpopMSFT
nodes.body: I don't believe most localization for .net 7 has been done yet. At least for the SDK, we are enabling that for RC1.

nodes.author: vdanche
nodes.body:
Still repro on NET7 RC2 SDK(7.0.100-rc.2.22471.15)
e.g TK
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65637796/192186874-8ea39fec-803c-4edf-a78c-0faa44800b88.png)

> 
> @joeloff good workloads introduction bug for @nagilson?

@marcpopMSFT some strings during publish still unlocalized in NET7 RC2.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65637796/192422787-ba0a8d5f-a5bf-442e-b274-c810687d200c.png)

That last one comes from the Blazor SDK @javiercn 
https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/blob/main/src/BlazorWasmSdk/Targets/Microsoft.NET.Sdk.BlazorWebAssembly.6_0.targets#L581

nodes.author: marcpopMSFT
nodes.body: I believe that last one is also part of the list from the runtime that @agocke would own.

nodes.author: nagilson
nodes.body: Unassigning as it's up to those teams to translate their messages

nodes.author: marcpopMSFT
nodes.body: Moving to runtime as the remaining strings come from here we believe.

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body:
It looks like we are missing localizations for several of the messages in the workloads.

cc @maraf @akoeplinger

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body: @akoeplinger ping

title: [Loc]With .NET 7 preview7 installed on locale OS, some strings are unlocalized during installing workload and publish in CLI.

author: lewing
body: We should add a wbt that checks the workload downlevel runtime versions against the new installer and fails if they are lower than the properties in eng/Versions.props

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body:
This will help but it will still be quite fragile because installer often doesn't update the downlevel versions until after we should have already changed ours.  We'll also need to do the same in emsdk to make sure that VS insertions go smoothly and we don't have the installer flow setup there (although we could add it)

cc @marcpopMSFT @joeloff

nodes.author: marcpopMSFT
nodes.body: If you're going off of the implicit version, I'm not sure this will work. Typically in VS main we'll have a .net preview that has N-1 implicit versions but N workloads. This is because VS added a package verification check that flags our workloads in main being behind their release branches. This check doesn't flag our implicit version/runtime.

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body: Yeah, we could do implicit+1 on preview branches😉. We need to know ahead of time the versions that will be inserted into VS for a given branch so I guess we need a mechanism that will allow that or we need to produce the downlevel manifests somewhere other than runtime.

title: [workloads] add wbt that checks downlevel runtime versions.

author: Bonicgamer
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
I've been trying to work on compiling [Opus](https://github.com/xiph/opus) and [SpeexDSP](https://github.com/xiph/speexdsp) to Wasm to be able to use it with a project called [VoiceCraft](https://github.com/AvionBlock/VoiceCraft), but it won't work because `wasm-opt` is getting passed `bulk-memory-opt` and `call-indirect-overlong` flags which support wasn't added for until v121 (The version that comes with the Emscripten SDK is v117). This is preventing me from continuing the work I've started [here](https://github.com/AvionBlock/VoiceCraft/pull/137).

### Describe the solution you'd like
Please update the Binaryen tools used in the .NET emsdk to v121 or higher.

### Additional context
To reproduce this you can simply compile [Opus](https://github.com/xiph/opus) by cloning the repo and doing:

```
./autogen.sh
mkdir build && cd build
emcmake cmake .. -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DOPUS_BUILD_PROGRAMS=OFF -DOPUS_STACK_PROTECTOR_HELP_STR=OFF -DOPUS_DISABLE_INTRINSICS_HELP_STR=ON -DCMAKE_C_FLAGS=-m32 -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS=-m32
emmake make # and then this should produce a file called "libopus.a"
```

Then include it with in your .csproj file with `<NativeFileReference Include="opus.a" />`

If you need and extra help to reproduce this let me know!

_P.S. Idk if this is the right place to ask this._

title: Please update Binaryen in emsdk

author: jozkee
body:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/114676 hardcoded `SdkVersionForWorkloadTesting` to 9.0.105, this is not good because it will break as soon as codeflow bumps the global.json version. 

See: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/115677#issuecomment-2957080374 and 
arcade codeflow CI: https://dev.azure.com/dnceng-public/public/_build/results?buildId=1057438&view=logs&j=1fa93050-f528-55d3-a351-f8bf9ce5adbf&t=d9dc6d3d-3442-5b70-1296-5b62e29ea209&l=78

cc @ericstj

nodes.author: dotnet-policy-service
nodes.body:
Tagging subscribers to 'arch-wasm': @lewing
See info in [area-owners.md](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/area-owners.md) if you want to be subscribed.
<!-- Policy app identification https://img.shields.io/static/v1?label=PullRequestIssueManagement. -->

nodes.author: jozkee
nodes.body: cc @akoeplinger, is there an alternative to updating `SdkVersionForWorkloadTesting` each time the global.json is updated? This is prone to errors, especially for folks unexperienced with codeflow.

nodes.author: akoeplinger
nodes.body: yeah I think we could add some logic to look at SdkVersionForWorkloadTesting and global.json and pick whatever version is higher

nodes.author: ericstj
nodes.body: Why do we even have a different version for this?  Can it just use whatever SDK is configured for the repo?

nodes.author: akoeplinger
nodes.body: No, the repo SDK is updated quite infrequently, the point of these tests is to test against the the latest SDK. At least that's how it works in main, for servicing it basically flips around since we usually don't have an sdk -> runtime flow so the SDK in global.json moves ahead.

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body: We could update the logic to use https://github.com/dotnet/msbuild/commit/2013004e99daa2e0b50f3581abd90640b63d4fd5 and use the Max (sdk flow, global.json)

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body:
> We could update the logic to use [dotnet/msbuild@2013004](https://github.com/dotnet/msbuild/commit/2013004e99daa2e0b50f3581abd90640b63d4fd5) and use the Max (sdk flow, global.json)

this sounded easy until I remembered how fun it is to try to deal with prerelease versions in msbuild

title: WASM: browser-wasm * Release WasmBuildTests don't use hardcoded SDK version

title: Crash during RunWithDifferentAppBundleLocations
